awd_titl_txt: Whittaker Models and p-Adic Deformation in the Langlands Program
awd_abstract_narration:
Primes numbers are integers, or whole numbers, which cannot be factored into a product of smaller integers. When considered as parts of larger and more abstract number systems, for example those containing imaginary numbers, there are several ways primes may factor. The splitting behavior of prime numbers is a fascinating and mysterious part of nature, and number theory is concerned with studying it systematically, especially by connecting it with the arithmetic of polynomials and the geometry of their solution sets. Over the past several decades, the Langlands program has revealed striking connections between these solution sets of polynomials and sets of symmetries that naturally occur in infinite-dimensional spaces. It has been especially fruitful in the Langlands program to consider the way these symmetries deform within families, and this project approaches two outstanding problems in this area by using the framework of Whittaker models to make them more concrete, or to turn them into explicit computational problems.

Spaces of Whittaker functions of automorphic forms are called Whittaker models. Symmetries in Whittaker models capture what is needed to construct L-functions in the Langlands program, in many cases. This project will study the deformation theory of Whittaker models in order to understand the behavior of Langlands reciprocity with respect to congruences modulo prime numbers, and with respect to deformation in families. The first goal is to generalize Ihara’s lemma by controlling congruences between automorphic forms in terms of their local Whittaker models. The approach is to use a computer to test, in many examples, the congruences that can occur in the action of the local Iwahori-Hecke algebra on a non-Eisenstein integral eigenform. The second goal is to formulate, and prove in the banal case, a local Langlands conjecture in families for reductive groups other than the general linear group, especially quasi-split groups that split over a tame extension. The approach is to construct a moduli space of Langlands parameters, study its geometry, and use converse theorems to connect it to the integral Bernstein center.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The major goals of this project were to use Whittaker models to study the way deformation theory behaves in the Langlands program. More concretely, the goal was to formulate a local Langlands conjecture in families that respects the natural deformation of representations on both sides of the local Langlands correspondence. Another goal of the project was to engage undergraduates or graduate students in research level projects involving gamma factors in the representation theory of general linear groups over finite fields.

Together with his co-authors the PI accomplished the publication of the manuscript titled "finiteness for Hecke algebras in p-adic groups" in a top journal: the Journal of the American Mathematical Society. This was the first paper to apply the ground-breaking new techniques of Fargues and Scholze to solve a concrete problem in the representation theory of p-adic groups over arbitrary coefficient rings where p is invertible, namely, the so-called second-adjointness theorem.

Together with four co-authors (two grad students, two postdocs, and one assistant professor in a different specialty), the PI produced a preprint and posted it on the arxiv. It is no undergoing review for a journal. The subject of the paper is gamma factors and converse theorems for general linear groups over finite fields, in the setting of modular representation theory. In the paper we use techniques inspired by the p-adic setting to prove a theorem in the finite fields case, resolving several new difficulties along the way.

Other than the two achievements listed in "major activities," the PI has written two other manuscripts that came out of work performed during the period of the grant. One is titled Toward a local theta correspondence in families for type II dual pairs, written together with a postdoc at Imperial College, and the other is titled The local Langlands correspondence in families part 1: the banal setting." Both manuscripts are written, but in both of them we have noticed one minor technical error in one of the paragraphs, which we are in the process of fixing. Both of these manuscripts will appear on Arxiv before the end of 2023.

The results have been posted in the arxiv as electronic preprints and submitted to journals for publication. The PI has delivered talks about the work in the project at the number theory seminar at McGill university as well as at a number theory conference at the university of Pittsburgh in May 2023.
